readability_reflection: It's difficult to provide specific examples without having them in front of me. However, in general, interpolation was more readable. Interpolation made it very clear where whitespace is preserved, even though it might be slightly more verbose. On the other hand, usages of interpolation where "{a} {b}" leads to "a b" rather than `a` and `b` being interpreted as variables were unclear/difficult to parse.
comprehension_debugging: There were many times where concatenation used literals in an unexpected way. For example, `"(0 1) " + 4 + ... + m` is confusing because I expect `m` to be a variable, not interpreted as text, because I do not expect `...` to be interpreted as text, and because I do not expect that to preserve whitespace. If the desired result is "(0 1) 4 + ... + m", I would expect that to be written "(0 1) " + 4 + " ... " + "m" with concatenation.
preference_rationale: Interpolation, because as I mentioned in question 1, the result is more predictable with less mental overhead.
learning_curve: Probably a lot! I have experience with string interpolation and concatenation in Python and Ruby primarily, but also Bash, fish, Java, C#... Ruby has by far my favorite syntax, followed by Python. In all of these, unquoted text is never interpreted as a literal, so that heavily flavors my understanding of your syntax.
suggestions_improvement: Pay attention to consistency of literal representation and preservation of whitespace.
